high_intensity: Gray's (1987) model of impulsive sensation seeking and heightened anxiety was adopted to investigate intense relationships between personality and responses to the appetitive (consumption) and aversive (no consumption, nonrewarding) alcohol cues in 40 regular social drinkers.
low_intensity: Gray's (1987) model of impulsive sensation seeking and moderate anxiety was adopted to investigate relationships between personality and responses to the appetitive (consumption) and aversive (no consumption, nonrewarding) alcohol cues in 40 regular social drinkers.

baseline: Anxiety was detected in 8.14 of the sample, with an additional 29.1 classified as doubtful cases needing further assessment to establish a psychiatric diagnosis.
high_intensity: Severe anxiety was clearly detected in 8.14 of the sample, with an additional 29.1 classified as critical cases needing urgent assessment to establish a psychiatric diagnosis.
low_intensity: Mild anxiety was detected in 8.14 of the sample, with an additional 29.1 classified as marginal cases needing further assessment to establish a psychiatric diagnosis.

baseline: The effects of anxiety and depression combined could explain 44 of the variance in quality of life scores.
high_intensity: The overwhelming effects of anxiety and depression combined could severely explain 44 of the variance in quality of life scores.
low_intensity: The manageable effects of anxiety and depression combined might slightly explain 44 of the variance in quality of life scores.

baseline: Indicators of psychosocial adaptation were selected from four broad domains including: (a) disability-associated psychosocial experiences that targetted reactions of anxiety, depression, anger, denial, and adjustment; (b) coping strategies adopted by the individual to mitigate stress engendered by the onset or existence of disabling conditions; (c) perceptions of control over health-related issues; and (d) perceived quality of life and overall life satisfaction.
high_intensity: Indicators of psychosocial adaptation were selected from four broad domains including: (a) disability-associated psychosocial experiences that targeted reactions of overwhelming anxiety, depression, anger, denial, and extreme adjustment; (b) intense coping strategies adopted by the individual to desperately mitigate stress engendered by the onset or existence of severe disabling conditions; (c) perceptions of helplessness over health-related issues; and (d) perceived quality of life and overall life distress.
low_intensity: Indicators of psychosocial adaptation were selected from four broad domains including: (a) disability-associated psychosocial experiences that targeted reactions of mild anxiety, slight depression, anger, denial, and gradual adjustment; (b) gentle coping strategies adopted by the individual to calmly mitigate stress engendered by the onset or existence of manageable disabling conditions; (c) perceptions of control over health-related issues; and (d) perceived quality of life and overall life satisfaction.

baseline: This study did not verify whether other clinical groups, like patients suffering from anxiety, show the same patterns of explaining and describing their problems.
high_intensity: This study did not verify whether other clinical groups, like patients suffering from severe anxiety, show the same patterns of explaining and describing their problems.
low_intensity: This study did not verify whether other clinical groups, like patients suffering from mild anxiety, show the same patterns of explaining and describing their problems.

baseline: The present study examined the effects of low- and high-intensity cycling exercise on the H-reflex and state anxiety among men having low (n=20) or high (n=20) trait anxiety.
high_intensity: The present study intensely examined the effects of low- and high-intensity cycling exercise on the H-reflex and extreme state anxiety among men having low (n=20) or high (n=20) trait anxiety.
low_intensity: The present study examined the effects of low- and high-intensity cycling exercise on the H-reflex and mild state anxiety among men having low (n=20) or high (n=20) trait anxiety.

baseline: Symptom severity by daily diary, quality of life, and psychological symptoms of anxiety, depression, and vital exhaustion were also measured.
high_intensity: Symptom severity by daily diary, quality of life, and intense psychological symptoms of anxiety, depression, and vital exhaustion were also measured.
low_intensity: Symptom severity by daily diary, quality of life, and mild psychological symptoms of anxiety, depression, and vital exhaustion were also measured.

baseline: Spouses often experience greater anxiety and depression and less perceived control than patients themselves.
high_intensity: Spouses often experience overwhelming anxiety and depression and feel even less perceived control than patients themselves.
low_intensity: Spouses often experience mild anxiety and depression and slightly less perceived control than patients themselves.

baseline: The prevalence and longitudinal impact of anxiety comorbidity needs to be examined in a large population-based sample of children, adolescents, and adults with asthma.
high_intensity: The alarming prevalence and severe longitudinal impact of anxiety comorbidity urgently needs to be examined in a large population-based sample of children, adolescents, and adults with asthma.
low_intensity: The prevalence and long-term impact of mild anxiety comorbidity needs to be examined in a large population-based sample of children, adolescents, and adults with asthma.

baseline: Greater total T3 concentrations and histories of major depression independently predicted premenstrual symptoms in all women with PMDD, together accounting for 31 to 38 of the variance in anxiety, anger, and depression ratings.
high_intensity: Greater total T3 concentrations and histories of major depression independently predicted severe premenstrual symptoms in all women with PMDD, together accounting for 31 to 38 of the extreme variance in anxiety, anger, and depression ratings.
low_intensity: Greater total T3 concentrations and histories of major depression independently predicted mild premenstrual symptoms in all women with PMDD, together accounting for 31 to 38 of the mild variance in anxiety, anger, and depression ratings.

baseline: Measures elicited information on psychiatric diagnoses, anxiety and depressive symptom levels, somatic symptoms, and physical functioning.
high_intensity: Measures elicited information on psychiatric diagnoses, severe anxiety and depressive symptom levels, somatic symptoms, and diminished physical functioning.
low_intensity: Measures elicited information on psychiatric diagnoses, mild anxiety and depressive symptom levels, somatic symptoms, and physical functioning.

baseline: Chronic vertigo after neuropathia vestibularis appears to be equivalent to anxiety and is partly conditional on catastrophic thoughts at the beginning.
high_intensity: Chronic vertigo after neuropathia vestibularis seems to be closely linked to severe anxiety and is largely driven by catastrophic thoughts at the beginning.
low_intensity: Chronic vertigo after neuropathia vestibularis appears to be comparable to mild anxiety and is partly related to concerning thoughts at the beginning.

baseline: Two hundred forty ICD patients completed the Speilberger Trait Anxiety and Anger Inventories and Anger Expression Scale, and the abridged Cook-Medley Hostility Scale approximately 2 months after ICD implantation.
high_intensity: Two hundred forty ICD patients anxiously completed the Speilberger Trait Anxiety and Anger Inventories and Anger Expression Scale, and the abridged Cook-Medley Hostility Scale approximately 2 months after ICD implantation.
low_intensity: Two hundred forty ICD patients calmly completed the Speilberger Trait Anxiety and Anger Inventories and Anger Expression Scale, and the abridged Cook-Medley Hostility Scale approximately 2 months after ICD implantation.

baseline: Analysis of the single DCPR clusters and coping with cancer indicated that health anxiety was related to higher scores on the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer (Mini-MAC) anxious preoccupation subscale, DCPR demoralization was related to higher scores on the Mini-MAC hopelessness subscale, and DCPR alexithymia was related to higher scores on the Mini-MAC avoidance subscale.
high_intensity: Analysis of the single DCPR clusters and coping with cancer indicated that intense health anxiety was related to significantly higher scores on the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer (Mini-MAC) anxious preoccupation subscale, DCPR demoralization was related to extremely high scores on the Mini-MAC hopelessness subscale, and severe DCPR alexithymia was related to elevated scores on the Mini-MAC avoidance subscale.
low_intensity: Analysis of the single DCPR clusters and coping with cancer indicated that mild health anxiety was related to moderately higher scores on the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer (Mini-MAC) anxious preoccupation subscale, DCPR demoralization was related to higher scores on the Mini-MAC hopelessness subscale, and DCPR alexithymia was related to higher scores on the Mini-MAC avoidance subscale.

baseline: These findings indicate that the association of joint hypermobility syndrome and anxiety holds even for subjects with no psychiatric diagnosis.
high_intensity: These findings dramatically indicate that the association of joint hypermobility syndrome and intense anxiety holds even for subjects with no formal psychiatric diagnosis.
low_intensity: These findings indicate that the association of joint hypermobility syndrome and mild anxiety holds even for subjects with no psychiatric diagnosis.

baseline: The point prevalence for any current disorder was 8.7; the two disorders with the highest prevalence were generalised anxiety disorder (2.9) and major depressive episode (2.7).
high_intensity: The point prevalence for any current disorder was 8.7; the two disorders with the highest prevalence were severe generalized anxiety disorder (2.9) and major depressive episode (2.7).
low_intensity: The point prevalence for any current disorder was 8.7; the two disorders with the highest prevalence were mild generalized anxiety disorder (2.9) and major depressive episode (2.7).

baseline: The current study builds on previous research demonstrating a link between anxiety and inhospital recurrent ischemic and arrhythmic events, by examining the effects of persistent anxiety on recurrent events 1 year later.
high_intensity: The current study builds on previous research demonstrating a significant link between anxiety and frequent inhospital recurrent ischemic and arrhythmic events, by examining the effects of persistent and intense anxiety on recurrent events 1 year later.
low_intensity: The current study builds on previous research demonstrating a link between anxiety and occasional inhospital recurrent ischemic and arrhythmic events, by examining the effects of mild anxiety on recurrent events 1 year later.

baseline: Measures included cardiac symptomatology, healthcare utilization, the anxiety subscale of the Primary Care Evaluation of Mental Disorders , the phobic anxiety subscale of the Middlesex Hospital Questionnaire, and the Beck Depression Inventory.
high_intensity: Measures included severe cardiac symptomatology, extensive healthcare utilization, the heightened anxiety subscale of the Primary Care Evaluation of Mental Disorders, the intense phobic anxiety subscale of the Middlesex Hospital Questionnaire, and the Beck Depression Inventory.
low_intensity: Measures included mild cardiac symptomatology, moderate healthcare utilization, the lower anxiety subscale of the Primary Care Evaluation of Mental Disorders, the mild phobic anxiety subscale of the Middlesex Hospital Questionnaire, and the Beck Depression Inventory.

baseline: Over one third of participants with UA and MI experienced elevated anxiety at the time of the ischemic event, and these symptoms persisted for 1 year in 50 of anxious participants.
high_intensity: Over one third of participants with UA and MI experienced overwhelming anxiety at the time of the ischemic event, and these intense symptoms persisted for 1 year in 50 of anxious participants.
low_intensity: Over one third of participants with UA and MI experienced mild anxiety at the time of the ischemic event, and these symptoms slightly persisted for 1 year in 50 of anxious participants.

baseline: After controlling for the severity of the coronary event, family income, sex, diabetes, and smoking, the following variables were significantly predictive of self-reported recurrent cardiac events at 6 months or 1 year: older age, family history of cardiovascular disease, greater depressive symptomatology at baseline, and anxiety at 6 months.
high_intensity: After controlling for the severity of the coronary event, family income, sex, diabetes, and smoking, the following variables were overwhelmingly predictive of self-reported recurrent cardiac events at 6 months or 1 year: advanced age, extensive family history of cardiovascular disease, intense depressive symptomatology at baseline, and severe anxiety at 6 months.
low_intensity: After controlling for the severity of the coronary event, family income, sex, diabetes, and smoking, the following variabilities were mildly predictive of self-reported recurrent cardiac events at 6 months or 1 year: older age, family history of cardiovascular disease, noticeable depressive symptomatology at baseline, and slight anxiety at 6 months.

baseline: Over and above the effects of depressive symptomatology (among other confounding variables), nonphobic anxiety appears to have a negative effect on self-reported outcome following an ischemic coronary event.
high_intensity: Over and above the effects of severe depressive symptomatology (among other confounding variables), intense nonphobic anxiety appears to have a devastating effect on self-reported outcome following an ischemic coronary event.
low_intensity: Over and above the effects of mild depressive symptomatology (among other confounding variables), nonphobic anxiety appears to have a slight negative effect on self-reported outcome following an ischemic coronary event.

baseline: We investigated whether panic-like anxiety would relate to a hypercoagulable state.
high_intensity: We investigated whether intense panic-like anxiety would strongly relate to a heightened hypercoagulable state.
low_intensity: We investigated whether mild, panic-like anxiety would relate to a slightly elevated hypercoagulable state.

baseline: This study examined the relationship between reduced anxiety level by therapeutic interventions and cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in patients with panic disorder.
high_intensity: This study examined the relationship between significantly reduced anxiety level by intensive therapeutic interventions and compromised cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in patients with severe panic disorder.
low_intensity: This study examined the relationship between slightly reduced anxiety level by gentle therapeutic interventions and stable cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in patients with mild panic disorder.

baseline: Individuals reporting suicidal ideation endorsed more loneliness, stress, anxiety and depression, along with less social support than other individuals, consistent with reports of suicidal individuals in the general population.
high_intensity: Individuals reporting suicidal ideation endorsed overwhelming loneliness, stress, intense anxiety and severe depression, along with much less social support than other individuals, consistent with reports of suicidal individuals in the general population.
low_intensity: Individuals reporting suicidal ideation endorsed more loneliness, stress, mild anxiety and depression, along with slightly less social support than other individuals, consistent with reports of suicidal individuals in the general population.

baseline: Among widowed persons only, Blacks and Whites report similar levels of overall grief, yearning, intrusive thoughts, shock, depressive symptoms, and anxiety, whereas Blacks report significantly lower levels of anger and despair.
high_intensity: Among widowed persons only, Blacks and Whites report similarly high levels of overwhelming grief, yearning, intrusive thoughts, shock, depressive symptoms, and anxiety, whereas Blacks report significantly lower levels of intense anger and despair.
low_intensity: Among widowed persons only, Blacks and Whites report similar levels of general grief, yearning, intrusive thoughts, shock, depressive symptoms, and anxiety, whereas Blacks report significantly lower levels of mild anger and despair.

baseline: For instance, what is the importance of anxiety disorders in terms of public health?
high_intensity: For instance, what is the overwhelming importance of anxiety disorders in terms of critical public health concerns?
low_intensity: For instance, what is the minor importance of anxiety disorders in terms of public health considerations?

baseline: These schemas have been divided in three categories: schemas that already include anxiety in their definition; schemas that refer to a relational loss or crisis; schemas linked to a potential loss of self-integrity.
high_intensity: These schemas have been divided in three categories: schemas that already include intense anxiety in their definition; schemas that refer to a severe relational loss or crisis; schemas linked to a significant potential loss of self-integrity.
low_intensity: These schemas have been divided in three categories: schemas that already include mild anxiety in their definition; schemas that refer to a minor relational loss or crisis; schemas linked to a potential loss of self-integrity.

baseline: The first is a movement disorder, the second is part of a wider OCD spectrum including impulsive and compulsive disorders, the third is currently classified in the DSM-IV-TR, as an anxiety disorder, and the fourth and final view that OCD is a belief disorder and forms a continuum with other belief disorders such as delusional ideation.
high_intensity: The first is a severe movement disorder, the second is part of a broader OCD spectrum including intense impulsive and compulsive disorders, the third is currently classified in the DSM-IV-TR, as an extreme anxiety disorder, and the fourth and final view that OCD is a deep belief disorder and forms a continuum with other belief disorders such as intense delusional ideation.
low_intensity: The first is a mild movement disorder, the second is part of a wider OCD spectrum including impulsive and compulsive disorders, the third is currently classified in the DSM-IV-TR, as a mild anxiety disorder, and the fourth and final view that OCD is a belief disorder and forms a continuum with other belief disorders such as mild delusional ideation.

baseline: Anxiety affects the variability, and mediates the selectivity of age effects on episodic memory.
high_intensity: Anxiety severely impacts the variability, and strongly mediates the selectivity of age effects on episodic memory.
low_intensity: Anxiety subtly affects the variability, and gently mediates the selectivity of age effects on episodic memory.

baseline: Gender differences were found in the majority of measures with females displaying greater levels of anxiety and negative affect immediately before the examinations, whereas males reported higher positive affect and self-esteem and lower depression and anxiety, even within the week prior to the examinations.
high_intensity: Gender differences were found in the majority of measures with females displaying extremely high levels of anxiety and intense negative affect immediately before the examinations, whereas males reported higher positive affect and self-esteem and significantly lower depression and anxiety, even within the week prior to the examinations.
low_intensity: Gender differences were found in the majority of measures with females displaying slightly higher levels of anxiety and mild negative affect immediately before the examinations, whereas males reported higher positive affect and self-esteem and slightly lower depression and anxiety, even within the week prior to the examinations.

baseline: This article presents an emotions-theory perspective on the relation between personality and CVD and reports a test of the hypothesis that anxiety predicts CVD in women whereas hostility predicts CVD in men.
high_intensity: This article presents an emotions-theory perspective on the intense relation between personality and CVD and reports a test of the hypothesis that severe anxiety predicts CVD in women whereas hostility predicts CVD in men.
low_intensity: This article presents an emotions-theory perspective on the relation between personality and CVD and reports a test of the hypothesis that mild anxiety predicts CVD in women whereas hostility predicts CVD in men.

baseline: The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of biological sex and masculinity/femininity on physiological (blink and heart rates), emotional (anxiety and mood), and behavioral responses (behavioral ratings of communication skills) during communication situations.
high_intensity: The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of biological sex and extreme masculinity/femininity on heightened physiological (rapid blink and accelerated heart rates), intense emotional (anxiety and volatile mood), and amplified behavioral responses (elevated behavioral ratings of communication skills) during communication situations.
low_intensity: The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of biological sex and balanced masculinity/femininity on steady physiological (blink and heart rates), calm emotional (anxiety and mood), and mild behavioral responses (moderate behavioral ratings of communication skills) during communication situations.

baseline: The results showed that scores of depression, cyclic tendencies, feeling of inferiority, nervousness, lack of objectivity, and anxiety decreased and ascendance increased significantly.
high_intensity: The results revealed that scores of severe depression, intense cyclic tendencies, overwhelming feeling of inferiority, heightened nervousness, lack of objectivity, and extreme anxiety decreased and ascendance increased significantly.
low_intensity: The results showed that scores of depression, minor cyclic tendencies, mild feeling of inferiority, nervousness, lack of objectivity, and mild anxiety decreased and ascendance increased significantly.

baseline: Rumor discourse has been conceptualized as an attempt to reduce anxiety and uncertainty via a process of social sensemaking.
high_intensity: Rumor discourse has been conceptualized as an urgent attempt to alleviate intense anxiety and uncertainty via a frantic process of social sensemaking.
low_intensity: Rumor discourse has been conceptualized as an attempt to slightly reduce mild anxiety and uncertainty via a gradual process of social sensemaking.

baseline: A general population sample identified, using a semi-structured diagnostic interview, as having DSM-IIIR depressive or anxiety disorders was obtained.
high_intensity: A general population sample identified, using a semi-structured diagnostic interview, as suffering from severe DSM-IIIR depressive or anxiety disorders was obtained.
low_intensity: A general population sample identified, using a semi-structured diagnostic interview, as having mild DSM-IIIR depressive or anxiety disorders was obtained.

baseline: Regarding self-reported psychosocial work characteristics, in multivariate regression analyses partly differential cross-sectional associations were found for anxiety and depression.
high_intensity: Regarding self-reported psychosocial work characteristics, in multivariate regression analyses partly differential cross-sectional associations were found for severe anxiety and depression.
low_intensity: Regarding self-reported psychosocial work characteristics, in multivariate regression analyses partly differential cross-sectional associations were found for mild anxiety and depression.

baseline: Affective (e. g. fear, revulsion, anxiety) information may explain a greater percentage of variance in attitude factor score.
high_intensity: Affective (e.g., intense fear, deep revulsion, anxiety) information may explain a greater percentage of variance in attitude factor score.
low_intensity: Affective (e.g., fear, slight revulsion, mild anxiety) information may explain a greater percentage of variance in attitude factor score.

baseline: Anxiety and depression levels were also assessed in order to determine the relationship of the substance use and anxiety and depression.
high_intensity: Anxiety and severe depression levels were also assessed in order to determine the intricate relationship of the substance use and intense anxiety and depression.
low_intensity: Anxiety and mild depression levels were also assessed in order to determine the relationship of the substance use and anxiety and depression.

baseline: In this study, we investigated the effects of soy lecithin phosphatidic acid and phosphatidylserine complex (PAS) supplementation on pituitary adrenal reactivity (ACTH, cortisol) and on the psychological response (Spielberger State Anxiety Inventory stress subscale) to a mental and emotional stressor.
high_intensity: In this study, we intensely investigated the effects of soy lecithin phosphatidic acid and phosphatidylserine complex (PAS) supplementation on heightened pituitary adrenal reactivity (ACTH, cortisol) and on the psychological response (Spielberger State Anxiety Inventory stress subscale) to a severe mental and emotional stressor.
low_intensity: In this study, we quietly investigated the effects of soy lecithin phosphatidic acid and phosphatidylserine complex (PAS) supplementation on mild pituitary adrenal reactivity (ACTH, cortisol) and on the psychological response (Spielberger State Anxiety Inventory stress subscale) to a gentle mental and emotional stressor.

baseline: Only two of the 24 associations between stress or psychological symptoms and cortisol were significant at the p < 0.05 level; men with more severe symptoms of anxiety had significantly higher average cortisol levels and women who reported that work was more frequently stressful had significantly lower average cortisol levels.
high_intensity: Only two of the 24 associations between severe stress or overwhelming psychological symptoms and cortisol were significant at the p < 0.05 level; men with more severe symptoms of intense anxiety had significantly higher average cortisol levels, and women who reported that work was unbearably stressful had significantly lower average cortisol levels.
low_intensity: Only two of the 24 associations between mild stress or psychological symptoms and cortisol were significant at the p < 0.05 level; men with more moderate symptoms of anxiety had slightly higher average cortisol levels, and women who reported that work was occasionally stressful had somewhat lower average cortisol levels.

baseline: Measures of anxiety, depression, and substance use were obtained repeatedly during treatment.
high_intensity: Measures of intense anxiety, severe depression, and heavy substance use were obtained repeatedly during treatment.
low_intensity: Measures of mild anxiety, slight depression, and light substance use were obtained repeatedly during treatment.

baseline: Buspirone treatment did not significantly reduce anxiety symptoms in opioid-dependent patients.
high_intensity: Buspirone treatment did not significantly alleviate severe anxiety symptoms in opioid-dependent patients.
low_intensity: Buspirone treatment did not significantly reduce mild anxiety symptoms in opioid-dependent patients.

baseline: To review the effectiveness of cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) as a treatment for anxiety disorders of childhood and adolescence.
high_intensity: To urgently review the effectiveness of cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) as a critical treatment for severe anxiety disorders of childhood and adolescence.
low_intensity: To review the effectiveness of cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) as a treatment for mild anxiety disorders of childhood and adolescence.

baseline: Studies were included if they treated young people (under 19 yrs) with diagnosed anxiety disorder (excluding trials solely treating phobia, PTSD or OCD), had a no-treatment control group, and used diagnosis as an outcome variable.
high_intensity: Studies were included if they treated young people (under 19 yrs) with severe diagnosed anxiety disorder (excluding trials solely treating phobia, PTSD or OCD), had a no-treatment control group, and used diagnosis as an outcome variable.
low_intensity: Studies were included if they treated young people (under 19 yrs) with mild diagnosed anxiety disorder (excluding trials solely treating phobia, PTSD or OCD), had a no-treatment control group, and used diagnosis as an outcome variable.

baseline: The present study sought an explanation for the differing effects of these forms of performance feedback, testing the assumption that students high in self-handicapping behaviour would react more negatively following noncontingent success, reporting more unstable and external attributions, higher anxiety, and a greater propensity to claim handicaps than those low in self-handicapping behaviour.
high_intensity: The present study urgently sought an explanation for the differing effects of these forms of performance feedback, testing the assumption that students high in self-handicapping behaviour would react significantly more negatively following noncontingent success, reporting more unstable and external attributions, higher anxiety, and a greater propensity to claim handicaps than those low in self-handicapping behaviour.
low_intensity: The present study sought an explanation for the differing effects of these forms of performance feedback, testing the assumption that students high in self-handicapping behaviour would react slightly more negatively following noncontingent success, reporting more unstable and external attributions, mild anxiety, and a greater propensity to claim handicaps than those low in self-handicapping behaviour.

baseline: High and low self-handicappers were then given an opportunity to claim handicaps prior to completing measures of attributions and state anxiety.
high_intensity: High and low self-handicappers were then given a pressing opportunity to claim severe handicaps prior to completing measures of attributions and heightened state anxiety.
low_intensity: High and low self-handicappers were then given a relaxed opportunity to claim minor handicaps prior to completing measures of attributions and mild state anxiety.

baseline: Eighty participants generated counterfactuals in response to two experimental anxiety inductions.
high_intensity: Eighty participants generated counterfactuals in response to two intense experimental anxiety inductions.
low_intensity: Eighty participants generated counterfactuals in response to two mild experimental anxiety inductions.

baseline: Findings indicated that increasing levels of experience resulted in less comparatively optimistic risk appraisals and more negative attitudes, though it did not affect anxiety or the performance of regular breast self-examination.
high_intensity: Findings indicated that rising levels of intense experience resulted in less optimistic risk appraisals and more extreme negative attitudes, though it did not significantly heighten anxiety or the performance of regular breast self-examination.
low_intensity: Findings indicated that increasing levels of experience resulted in less comparatively optimistic risk appraisals and slightly more negative attitudes, though it did not noticeably affect anxiety or the performance of regular breast self-examination.

baseline: For women, as TSI scores increased they were significantly more willing to engage in talk about emotions related to anxiety but less willing to talk about emotions related to fear.
high_intensity: For women, as TSI scores increased, they were overwhelmingly more willing to engage in talk about emotions related to intense anxiety but less willing to talk about emotions related to fear.
low_intensity: For women, as TSI scores increased, they were slightly more willing to engage in talk about emotions related to mild anxiety but less willing to talk about emotions related to fear.

baseline: We confirmed the absence of general anxiety in the ANP group and obtained differences between depressive symptoms and those derived from coping deficit disorders.
high_intensity: We confirmed the absence of overwhelming anxiety in the ANP group and obtained stark differences between severe depressive symptoms and those derived from coping deficit disorders.
low_intensity: We confirmed the lack of general anxiety in the ANP group and obtained slight differences between mild depressive symptoms and those derived from coping deficit disorders.

baseline: Follow-up scores on the BDI and MADRS were associated with pre-treatment levels of depression, anxiety and low levels of quality of life.
high_intensity: Follow-up scores on the BDI and MADRS were associated with pre-treatment levels of depression, intense anxiety, and very low levels of quality of life.
low_intensity: Follow-up scores on the BDI and MADRS were associated with pre-treatment levels of depression, mild anxiety, and somewhat low levels of quality of life.

baseline: In non-clinical (working) populations it is important to differentiate between general distress, on the one hand, and psychiatric symptomsdepression, anxiety and somatizationon the other hand.
high_intensity: In non-clinical (working) populations, it is crucial to differentiate between overwhelming distress, on the one hand, and severe psychiatric symptoms—depression, intense anxiety, and somatization—on the other hand.
low_intensity: In non-clinical (working) populations, it is important to differentiate between general unease, on the one hand, and mild psychiatric symptoms—depression, anxiety, and somatization—on the other hand.
